nodes.text: Characterize how soft errors in DNN accelerators propagate to DNN application outputs and develop cost-effective mitigation techniques for DNN systems

We perform large-scale fault injection experiments by modifying a DNN simulator to inject transient single-bit faults into datapaths and buffers of DNN accelerator abstractions using four convolutional networks and multiple data types
We analyze sensitivity to four parameters: network topology and data type, bit position and value, layer type and position (including normalization), and hardware data reuse implemented via buffers

We calculate FIT rates for datapath and buffer components using a projected raw FIT and measured SDC probabilities and perform a case study on the Eyeriss accelerator microarchitecture projected to 16nm

We design two mitigation techniques based on characterization: a symptom-based software detector that checks activation value ranges per layer, and selective latch hardening in hardware targeting sensitive bits
Networks used: ConvNet (CIFAR-10), AlexNet, CaffeNet, NiN (ImageNet); data types: DOUBLE, FLOAT, FLOAT16, and fixed-point variants 32b_rb26, 32b_rb10, 16b_rb10
Datapath fault injection results show SDC probabilities depend strongly on data type and network topology; shallower networks and larger dynamic range types produce higher SDC rates
Buffer fault injection on Eyeriss shows buffer SDC probabilities and projected FIT rates are often orders of magnitude higher than datapath due to larger size and reuse causing repeated reads
Bit-position sensitivity: for floating point, high-order exponent bits cause most SDCs; for fixed point, high-order integer bits are most vulnerable; vulnerability scales with dynamic value range
Value-deviation observation: faults that cause large magnitude deviations of activations are much more likely to cause SDCs; correct activation values are typically clustered near zero in layers

Layer and normalization effect: normalization layers (e.g., LRN) and operations like pooling and ReLU mask many faults; layers after normalization can show increased vulnerability if value ranges narrow

Data reuse effect: architectural buffers introduced to exploit weight, image, and output reuse (e.g., filter SRAM, img reg, psum reg) increase FIT because faults in buffers can be read many times and spread
Measured and projected FIT rates indicate unprotected Eyeriss accelerator components can exceed automotive safety FIT budgets (ISO 26262); applying protections can reduce FIT into acceptable ranges

Symptom-based detector (SED): learn per-layer activation value bounds from golden runs, check global buffer fmap values asynchronously at layer boundaries; detects SDC-causing faults that produce out-of-range activations
Selective latch hardening (SLH): prioritize hardening of latches corresponding to most SDC-sensitive bits using a mix of hardened latch designs to optimize area versus FIT reduction

Conclusion on design implications: choose data types with just-enough dynamic range, include normalization where possible, protect sensitive buffers and bits rather than naively applying full replication, and combine software detectors with selective hardware hardening

Evaluation of mitigations: SED achieved average precision 90.21% and recall 92.5% across selected networks and data types and reduced projected Eyeriss FIT substantially; SLH combinations achieve up to 100x latch FIT reduction with roughly 20%-25% latch area overhead
